results.title: Recently 2
results.brief_description: In Jochen Kuchen’s playful animated short ‘Recently 2’ a man undertakes a new medical procedure that allows him to see everything inside his body. What he discovers however is an inner world brimming with memories, hopes, dreams and disillusionment. Beautifully conveyed by blending various styles of animation, this evocative work ultimately explores not the building blocks of the body, but those of the soul.

results.title: Reassemblage: from the firelight to the screen
results.brief_description: This poetic yet intellectually rigorous documentary begins as an essay on Sengalese women but transforms to become an essay on the very subject of documentation, historical truth and Eurocentric “objectivity”. Trinh T. Minh-ha’s work has been pivotal in challenging cinematic assumptions about the representation of being “other”. Combining passionate theory with elegiac images “Reassemblage” is a critical history of the documentary and ethnography and one of the key works of Post-Colonial cinema.

results.title: Real wild child: Australian rock music & culture 1950's-90's (PC & MAC)
results.brief_description: A wild, surreal, multimedia ride through five decades of Australian rock music, focusing on seven major eras. Stroll to the milkbar to experience the music of 1956-63. Sneak into a girl’s bedroom to find out what was happening there between 1964-68. Take a trip to the hippie’s house to discover the meaning of music during 1969-73. Front up to the TV studio to study the impact of what unfolded between 1974-77. Circle the perimeter of the room at the Hotel to get the low-down on the happenings of 1978-83. Gatecrash the nightclub to observe interesting phenomena occurring between 1984-89, until finally hauling your tired body into a deck chair in the 1990’s garage to conclude the exploration. Fabulously presented, with informative snippets of information, excellent graphics and soundtrack, as well as cameos by some of Australia’s most well known (and often notorious) identities. SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: For Windows, 486 DX2/66 or better (Pentium recommended) running Windows 95 (recommended)/NT 4.0/Windows 3.1, 16 megabytes or more of RAM. Double speed or faster CD-ROM drive (Quad speed recommended), sound card (stereo 16-bit recommended), 640x480 Super VGA display (256 colour or better). For Macintosh 68040 or better (Power PC recommended) running Mac OS System 7.5 or later. 8 megabytes if application RAM, (ie. memory available after System requirements) double speed or faster CD-ROM drive (Quad speed recommended), 640x480 display (256 colour or better).

results.title: Readicut rugs
results.brief_description: Shows the birth of the world’s wool industry in England. Takes the viewer through the stages of rug-making from selected English wool to the manufacturing processes.

results.title: Rape: the right to resist
results.creator_credit: Pat Shields, Elinor Shields and Mercenary Productions
results.brief_description: Presents the positive options that a woman has available to her under attack or attempted rape conditions. Shows her how to face her assailant and the strategies to be employed in evading and ultimately escaping.

results.title: Radio view of the universe
results.creator_credit: Bert Shapiro, Alfred Butterfield and Modern Learning Aids
results.brief_description: In this film, Dr M.S. Roberts of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory in Green Bank, West Virginia, explains the use of the radio line of atomic hydrogen in determining the total hydrogen content of galaxies external to the Milky Way. He then establishes the strong correlation between hydrogen content and galactic shape and raises the question as to whether this correlation can be used as an indicator of galactic evolution.

results.title: Radio day
results.brief_description: A promotional exercise that shows a day in the life of radio station 3XY in Melbourne. Although most of the activities carried out in a commercial radio station are depicted, there is no attempt to explain why and as such this production does little to demystify the process. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Rachel Strickland presentation 2000-06-26
results.brief_description:
Rachel Strickland was invited by Ross Gibson to provide her thoughts on Federation Square, and the relevance of her work to it. Strickland views herself as an architect and an artist - “fashioning places and experiences that have a purpose”. The focus of her work, “Portable effects” is about the architectural design, and the many dimensions of architectural space that are not particularly well suited to a linear or narrative structure. She discusses the relationship between her work and cinema, and excerpts are played of everyday nomads such as Thelma Gehry, explaining why they have chosen to carry certain objects in their hand luggage.
She then moves on to describe how relationships were established between the 100 portable portraits to construct an interactive experience on CDROM, as well as briefly outlining interface design and database structure. Strickland finishes with the completion of a project to create a multimedia experience that introduces people to design. There is a video presentation of the exhibit - “Portable effects: a survey of nomadic design practice”, held at the Exploratorium in San Francisco, CA, 1 March - 1 June, 1997. The exhibition captured people’s transactions with objects from their own portable systems.
